I think B. A is wrong for sure, you need at least Python 3.7 to run scripts on your endpoint directly. https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Pro-Administrator-Guide/Run-Scripts-on-an-Endpoint

choices.A: Any version of Python script can be run.
choices.B: The level of risk is assigned to the script upon import.
choices.D: The script is run on the machine uploading the script to ensure that it is operational.
choices.C: Any script can be imported including Visual Basic (VB) scripts.

questions.question_text: Which statement regarding scripts in Cortex XDR is true?

choices.B: WildFire is the engine that runs on the local agent and determines whether behavioural threats are occurring on the endpoint.
choices.C: WildFire accepts and analyses a sample to provide a verdict.
choices.D: WildFire runs entirely on the agent to quickly analyse samples and provide a verdict.
choices.A: WildFire runs in the cloud and analyses alert data from the XDR agent to check for behavioural threats.

questions.question_text: What is the function of WildFire for Cortex XDR?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Only in windows, not Linux

To initiate remediation suggestions, you must meet the following requirements:

Cortex XDR Pro per Endpoint license

An App Administrator, Privileged Responder, or Privileged Security Admin role permissions which include the remediation permissions

EDR data collection enabled

Agent version 7.2 and above on Windows endpoints

Selected Answer: A
Remediation Suggestions is available only for Windows, so the answer C is Incorrect.
B and D are also incorrect, there is no X2go or NFS, instead, there is "Live Terminal"

@ Blahziblah 
Please check your referred video. I think "A" is the right option.

Selected Answer: C
yes remediation suggestions lets you delete the file, the keyword in C "automatically" is problematic for me. it is the best choice out of these though.

Selected Answer: C
I think the answer is C. See this overview from Palo Alto: https://youtu.be/HBzxmSjHYt4?si=JqjrLZkLTXBeqXpp&t=452. Here he talks about deleting a file through the Remediation Suggestions.

choices.B: Open X2go from the Cortex XDR console and delete the file via X2go.
choices.C: Initiate Remediate Suggestions to automatically delete the file.
choices.A: Manually remediate the problem on the endpoint in question.
choices.D: Open an NFS connection from the Cortex XDR console and delete the file.

questions.question_text: A Linux endpoint with a Cortex XDR Pro per Endpoint license and Enhanced Endpoint Data enabled has reported malicious activity, resulting in the creation of a file that you wish to delete. Which action could you take to delete the file?
Which of the following best defines the Windows Registry as used by the Cortex XDR agent?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The Windows Registry is indeed a hierarchical database, meaning it organizes its data in a tree structure with keys and subkeys, similar to folders and files.

choices.D: a ledger for maintaining accurate and up-to-date information on total disk usage and disk space remaining available to the operating system
choices.B: a system of files used by the operating system to commit memory that exceeds the available hardware resources. Also known as the “swap”
choices.C: a central system, available via the internet, for registering officially licensed versions of software to prove ownership
choices.A: a hierarchical database that stores settings for the operating system and for applications

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The answer should be C. See the following documention by Palo Alto:
1) "BTP prevents sophisticated attacks that leverage built-in OS executables and common administration utilities by continuously monitoring endpoint activity for malicious causality chains"
2) "Palo Alto Networks researchers define the causality chains that are malicious and distribute those chains as behavioral threat rules. When the Cortex XDR agent detects a match to a behavioral threat protection rule, the Cortex XDR agent carries out the configured action (default is Block)."

1) https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Pro-Administrator-Guide/Endpoint-Protection-Capabilities
2) https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Prevent-Administrator-Guide/Add-a-New-Malware-Security-Profile

questions.question_text: Which statement best describes how Behavioral Threat Protection (BTP) works?

choices.C: BTP matches EDR data with rules provided by Cortex XDR.
choices.A: BTP injects into known vulnerable processes to detect malicious activity.
choices.B: BTP runs on the Cortex XDR and distributes behavioral signatures to all agents.
choices.D: BTP uses machine Learning to recognize malicious activity even if it is not known.
